"gram": "Decision tree learning uses a decision tree as a predictive model which maps observations about an item to conclusions about the item's target value. It is one of the predictive modelling approaches used in statistics
column3: data mining and machine learning. Tree models where the target variable can take a finite set of values are called classification trees. In these tree structures
column4: leaves represent class labels and branches represent conjunctions of features that lead to those class labels. Decision trees where the target variable can take continuous values (typically real numbers) are called regression trees. In decision analysis
column5: a decision tree can be used to visually and explicitly represent decisions and decision making. In data mining
column6: a decision tree describes data but not decisions; rather the resulting classification tree can be an input for decision making. This page deals with decision trees in data mining."

"gram": "Association rule learning is a method for discovering interesting relations between variables in large databases. It is intended to identify strong rules discovered in databases using different measures of interestingness.[1] Based on the concept of strong rules
column3: Rakesh Agrawal et al.[2] introduced association rules for discovering regularities between products in large-scale transaction data recorded by point-of-sale (POS) systems in supermarkets. For example
column5: potatoes}\} \Rightarrow \{\mathrm{burger}\} found in the sales data of a supermarket would indicate that if a customer buys onions and potatoes together
column6: they are likely to also buy hamburger meat. Such information can be used as the basis for decisions about marketing activities such as
column8: promotional pricing or product placements. In addition to the above example from market basket analysis association rules are employed today in many application areas including Web usage mining
column11: and bioinformatics. In contrast with sequence mining
column12: association rule learning typically does not consider the order of items either within a transaction or across transactions."

column4: also support vector networks[1]) are supervised learning models with associated learning algorithms that analyze data and recognize patterns
column5: used for classification and regression analysis. Given a set of training examples
column6: each marked for belonging to one of two categories
column7: an SVM training algorithm builds a model that assigns new examples into one category or the other
column8: making it a non-probabilistic binary linear classifier. An SVM model is a representation of the examples as points in space
column9: mapped so that the examples of the separate categories are divided by a clear gap that is as wide as possible. New examples are then mapped into that same space and predicted to belong to a category based on which side of the gap they fall on."

"gram": "Inductive logic programming (ILP) is a subfield of machine learning which uses logic programming as a uniform representation for examples
column3: background knowledge and hypotheses. Given an encoding of the known background knowledge and a set of examples represented as a logical database of facts
column4: an ILP system will derive a hypothesised logic program which entails all the positive and none of the negative examples."

column14: and genetic algorithms. In the operations research and control literature

"gram": "Premium-rate telephone numbers are telephone numbers for telephone calls during which certain services are provided
